lines.text: Enter SPEED and LAUNCE severally

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Launce! by mine honesty, welcome to Milan!

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Forswear not thyself, sweet youth, for I am not welcome. I reckon this always, that a man is never undone till he be hanged, nor never welcome to a place till some certain shot be paid and the hostess say 'Welcome!'

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Come on, you madcap, I'll to the alehouse with you presently; where, for one shot of five pence, thou shalt have five thousand welcomes. But, sirrah, how did thy master part with Madam Julia?

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Marry, after they closed in earnest, they parted very fairly in jest.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: But shall she marry him?

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: How then? shall he marry her?

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: No, neither.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: What, are they broken?

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: No, they are both as whole as a fish.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Why, then, how stands the matter with them?

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Marry, thus: when it stands well with him, it stands well with her.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: What an ass art thou! I understand thee not.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: What a block art thou, that thou canst not! My staff understands me.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: What thou sayest?

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Ay, and what I do too: look thee, I'll but lean, and my staff understands me.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: It stands under thee, indeed.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Why, stand-under and under-stand is all one.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: But tell me true, will't be a match?

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Ask my dog: if he say ay, it will! if he say no, it will; if he shake his tail and say nothing, it will.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: The conclusion is then that it will.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Thou shalt never get such a secret from me but by a parable.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: 'Tis well that I get it so. But, Launce, how sayest thou, that my master is become a notable lover?

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: I never knew him otherwise.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Than how?

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: A notable lubber, as thou reportest him to be.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Why, thou whoreson ass, thou mistakest me.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Why, fool, I meant not thee; I meant thy master.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: I tell thee, my master is become a hot lover.

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Why, I tell thee, I care not though he burn himself in love. If thou wilt, go with me to the alehouse; if not, thou art an Hebrew, a Jew, and not worth the name of a Christian.

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: Why?

lines.speaker: launce
lines.text: Because thou hast not so much charity in thee as to go to the ale with a Christian. Wilt thou go?

lines.speaker: speed
lines.text: At thy service.
Exeunt
